title: Verb Basics & Present Tense
context: Korean verbs are the engine of sentences. You need only the verb to make a full idea!
Dictionary forms end with -다. To speak politely, you change that ending to -아요/어요/해요.
Most verbs follow simple patterns once you know the final vowel.

sentences.english: I drink water. I drink coffee too.

explanation: Drop 다 and add -아요 after bright vowels (ㅏ/ㅗ): 가다 → 가요, 보다 → 봐요. Add -어요 after other vowels: 먹다 → 먹어요, 마시다 → 마셔요.
하다 verbs always become 해요: 하다 → 해요 (운동해요, 공부해요, 일해요).
은/는 marks topics, 이/가 marks subjects. You can often omit them in casual speech when context is clear.
Present tense in Korean covers present and near future, like 'I go/I will go' depending on context.
Stress syllables smoothly. No strong stress like English; keep rhythm even.

messages.speaker: 지수
messages.english: Hello, Minho! Are you eating lunch today?

messages.speaker: 민호
messages.korean: 네, 지금 점심 먹어요. 물도 마셔요.
messages.english: Yes, I'm eating lunch now. I drink water too.
messages.romanization: ne, jigeum jeomsim meogeoyo. muldo masyeoyo.

messages.speaker: 지수
messages.korean: 저는 커피 마셔요. 점심 먹고 집에 가요.
messages.english: I drink coffee. After lunch I go home.
messages.romanization: jeoneun keopi masyeoyo. jeomsim meokgo jibe gayo.

messages.speaker: 민호
messages.korean: 저는 지금 집에 와요. 서울에 살아요.
messages.english: I'm coming home now. I live in Seoul.
messages.romanization: jeoneun jigeum jibe wayo. seoure salayo.

messages.speaker: 지수
messages.english: What do you do at home?

messages.speaker: 민호
messages.english: I watch a drama at home. Do you know the drama?

messages.speaker: 지수
messages.english: Yes, I know it. I watch it too.
